entry.title: The exponent in the Łojasiewicz inequality
entry.summary:
Let $f$ be a real-analytic function defined on an open neighborhood $U$ of $0$ in $\mathbb R^n$.

Suppose that $|\nabla f(x)| \ge \theta |x|^k$ for any $x \in U$, where $\theta>0$ is a constant and $k \ge 2$ is an integer.

Can we prove $$ |f(x)-f(0)| \le C |\nabla f(x)|^{\frac{k+1}{k}} $$ for any $x$ in a neighborhood of $0$?

entry.title: Ten new conjectural series for $\frac{\log m}{\pi}$ involving harmonic numbers
entry.summary:
Recall that the harmonic numbers are given by $$H_n:=\sum_{0<k\le n}\frac1k\ \ \ \ (n=0,1,2,\ldots).$$ As a supplement to Question 436205 and my related paper Series with summands involving harmonic numbers, here I pose some new conjectural series involving harmonic numbers which are motivated by calssical Ramanujan-type series. Namely, based on my computation, recently I conjectured the following ten identities:

\begin{align}\sum_{k=0}^\infty\frac{\binom{2k}k^2\binom{3k}k}{(-192)^{k}} \left((5k+1)(H_{2k}-H_k)+\frac{3k+1}{2k+1}\right)&=\frac{4\log3}{\sqrt3\,\pi}, \tag{1} \\\sum_{k=0}^\infty\frac{\binom{2k}k^2\binom{3k}k}{(-192)^{k}} \left((5k+1)(H_{3k}-H_k)+\frac{4k+3}{6k+3}\right)&=\frac4{3\sqrt3\,\pi}\log\frac{64}3, \tag{2} \\\sum_{k=0}^\infty\frac{\binom{2k}k^2\binom{3k}k}{(-12)^{3k}} \left((51k+7)(H_{2k}+H_k)-\frac{3(13k+7)}{2k+1}\right)&=-36\sqrt3\frac{\log3}{\pi},\tag{3} \\\sum_{k=0}^\infty\frac{\binom{2k}k^2\binom{3k}k}{(-12)^{3k}} \left((51k+7)(3H_{3k}-7H_k)-\frac{180k+93}{2k+1}\right)&=36\sqrt3\frac{\log108}{\pi} \tag{4} \\\sum_{k=0}^\infty\frac{\binom{2k}k^2\binom{3k}k}{(-8640)^{k}} \left((9k+1)(H_{2k}-2H_k)-\frac{27k+13}{6k+3}\right)&=\frac{48\log 3}{\sqrt{15}\,\pi} \tag{5} \\\sum_{k=0}^\infty\frac{\binom{2k}k^2\binom{3k}k}{(-8640)^{k}} \left((9k+1)(3H_{3k}-H_k)+\frac{1}{6k+3}\right)&=\frac{12}{\sqrt{15}\,\pi}\log\frac{320}{243},\tag{6} \\\sum_{k=0}^\infty\frac{\binom{2k}k^2\binom{4k}{2k}} {(-3\times2^{12})^{k}}\left((28k+3)(H_{2k}-H_k)+\frac{20k+9}{4k+2}\right)&=\frac{4\log432}{\sqrt3\,\pi}, \tag{7} \\\sum_{k=0}^\infty\frac{\binom{2k}k^2\binom{4k}{2k}} {(-3\times2^{12})^{k}}\left((28k+3)(H_{4k}-H_{2k})+\frac{8k+5}{4k+2}\right)&=\frac{8}{\sqrt3\,\pi}\log\frac{16}3, \tag{8} \\\sum_{k=0}^\infty\frac{\binom{2k}k\binom{3k}k\binom{6k}{3k}} {(-15)^{3k}}\left((63k+8)(3H_{2k}-5H_k)+\frac{198k+83}{4k+2}\right)&=30\sqrt{15}\frac{\log3}{\pi}, \tag{9} \end{align} and $$\begin{aligned}&\sum_{k=0}^\infty\frac{\binom{2k}k\binom{3k}k\binom{6k}{3k}} {(-96)^{3k}}\left((342k+25)(3H_{2k}-7H_k)+\frac{1122k+571}{2k+1}\right) \\&\qquad=64\sqrt{6}\frac{\log(2^73^6)}{\pi}.\end{aligned} \tag{10}$$

For example, $(1)$ and $(2)$ are motivated by Ramanujann's series $$\sum_{k=0}^\infty(5k+1)\frac{\binom{2k}k^2\binom{3k}k}{(-192)^k}=\frac{4\sqrt3}{\pi}.$$

One can easily check the identities $(1)-(10)$ numerically via Mathematica since the ten series converge at geometric rates. For all the ten conjectural identities, I also have corresponding conjectural $p$-adic congruences.

QUESTION. Any ideas to prove some of the ten conjectural identities $(1)-(10)$? Can the WZ method be helpful?

entry.title: Connectivity of the intersection complex of surfaces of revolution in a unit $n$-cube
entry.summary:
In a unit $n$-cube $(n\ge 2)$ centered at the origin in $\Bbb R^n$, if we define embeddings of smooth enclosed $n$-volume maximizing, $(n-1)$ dim. surfaces of revolution about all of the $2^{n-1}$ long diagonals that satisfy fixed dirichlet boundary conditions at the vertex pairs under a rigid metric, must the union of their pairwise codimension two intersections always form a connected set?

It is assumed that the boundary conditions at the vertex pairs and the rigid metric uniquely determine the $(n-1)$ surfaces of revolution about the long diagonals of a unit $n$-cube.

This is a wireframe model of the complex for $n=3$. Not shown is the connected set of pairwise intersections - however it turns out to be an octahedral graph. The surfaces are defined by a "momentum profile" $\phi(u) = au - bu^2$, where the Gaussian curvature $K_\phi = - \frac{1}{2} \phi''(u)$ is constant and positive. The metric on each surface is:$$ds^2 = \frac{1}{\phi(u)} du^2 + \phi(u) dv^2$$ The profile $\phi(u)$ is chosen so that the surface fits within the cube and closes exactly at the antipodal vertices. For $a = 2/\sqrt{3}$, we get a unique $b > 0$ :$$\int_0^{a/b} \sqrt{\frac{1 - \frac{1}{4} \phi'(u)^2}{\phi(u)}} \, du = \sqrt{3}$$

The $n=2$ case is trivial. The pairwise codimension two intersection is $p=(0,0)$. A point is connected. As I alluded to above, the $n=3$ case is already nontrivial but the connected set is $3$ loops (forming an octahedral graph). The $n=4$ case means we have $8$ topological $S^3$'s (3-spheres) pairwise intersecting.

The complexity explodes from here, but I strongly suspect the above claim is true, but can't rule out some large critical dimension where it fails.

entry.title: Sharp $L^{\infty}$ Bernstein inequality for bandlimited functions with 2D square symmetry
entry.summary:
This is a follow-up to this question. Based on that question, the following sharp $L^{\infty}$ Bernstein inequality for bandlimited functions is known:

Suppose $f(x)$ is a smooth function $\mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that $\hat{f}$ exists and is supported on the ball of radius $A$ centered at the origin. Then $$ \| \partial^{\alpha} f\|_{\infty} \le 2 \pi A \|f\|_{\infty}. $$ for any first-order partial derivative $\partial^{\alpha}$.

Here, we use the convention that the Fourier transform is $$ \hat{f}(k) = \int_{\mathbb{R}^n} f(x) e^{-2 \pi i \langle k, x \rangle} \, dx. $$

I'm interested in the 2D case $n = 2$. No matter the dimension, the extremal functions are precisely trig functions; in particular trig functions with one-dimensional behavior. For example, for $n = 2$, extremal functions include $f(x,y) = \cos(2 \pi A x)$ or $f(x,y) = \sin(2 \pi A y)$.

My question: If we impose some simple 2D symmetry constraints such as symmetry under the dihedral group $D_4$, or maybe just $\pi/2$ rotational symmetry, in order to exclude these "1D" extremal trig functions, can the Bernstein inequality be rigorously sharpened, and if so, is there existing literature?

In particular, my intuition would lead me to believe that under such square symmetries, extremal functions would look like $$ f(x,y) = \cos(2 \pi A x) + \cos(2 \pi A y), $$ in which case I'd conjecture the sharper inequality is $$ \|\partial^{\alpha} f\|_{\infty} \le \sqrt{2} \pi A \|f\|_{\infty}. $$

entry.title: Conceptual interpretation of $\alpha$-recursion theorems: What do they tell us about the nature of computability on admissible ordinals?
entry.summary:
I found this question and while searching for information about it, some questions came to mind (I hope they are appropriate for the site). Let us consider the following definitions and theorems (which I consider essential):

Definition: $x$ is $\alpha$-finite if and only if $x\in L_{\alpha}$ and $x\subset \gamma$, for some $\gamma<\alpha$.

Definition 1: A set $A\subset\alpha$ is said to be $\alpha$-regular if for every $\gamma<\alpha$, $A\cap \gamma$ is $\alpha$-finite.

Definition 2: A set $A\subset\alpha$ is said to be amenable if for every $U\in L_{\alpha}$, $A\cap U\in L_{\alpha}$. In other words, the intersection of $A$ with any $\alpha$-finite set remains $\alpha$-finite.

Theorem 1: If $\alpha$ is an admissible ordinal, then $A\subset\alpha$ is $\alpha$-regular if and only if it is amenable.

Definition: Let $\alpha$ be a limit ordinal. A set $A\subseteq\alpha$ is tame recursively enumerable (t.r.e.) if there exists an enumeration $\{A^{\sigma}\}_{\sigma<\alpha}$ such that, for every $K\subseteq A$ with $K$ $\alpha$-finite, $\exists \sigma<\alpha (K\subseteq A^{\sigma})$.

Theorem 2: Let $\alpha$ be an admissible ordinal and $A\subseteq\alpha$; then $A$ is r.e. if and only if $A$ is t.r.e.

Theorem: Let $A,B\subseteq\omega$. $B\leq_T A$ if and only if $B\in \Delta_1^A$.

Definition: The Turing degree of $A$ is defined by $\mathrm{deg}_T(A)=\{ B : B\in\Delta_1^A \wedge A\in\Delta_1^B \}$.

Definition: The $\alpha$-degree of $A$ is defined by $\mathrm{deg}_{\alpha}(A)=\{ B\subseteq\alpha : B\in\Delta_1^{\alpha}(A) \wedge A\in\Delta_1^{\alpha}(B) \}$.

Theorem 3: Let $\alpha$ be an admissible ordinal; then every r.e. set has the same $\alpha$-degree as some regular r.e. set.

I have no problem understanding the proofs; but my question is, how are these results interpreted? Many texts say that admissible ordinals have recursive/computational behavior very similar to $\omega$. Do these results (the enumerated theorems) help confirm that fact? Or is it simply due to the recursive nature of $\Sigma_1-$recursion? In any case, can I (somehow) interpret these results in a computational/recursive way?

entry.title: Compatibility of definitions of manifolds between atlas and structure ring in abstract setting
entry.summary:
Let $M$ be an $n$-dimensional topological manifold, i.e. second countable, Hausdorff, and locally homeomorphic to $\Bbb R^n$. There are two ways to define the $C^k$ differential structure of $M$:

  • Atlas: a maximal collection $\mathcal A_M$ of homeomorphisms $\phi:U\subseteq M\to\phi(U)\subseteq\Bbb R^n$ such that $\phi\circ\psi^{-1}$ are $C^k$-diffeomorphisms between open sets of $\Bbb R^n$.

  • Locally ringed space: A sheaf $\mathcal O_M$ of rings such that $(M,\mathcal O_M)$ is locally sheaf isomorphic to $(\Bbb R^n,C^k_{\Bbb R^n})$. We can assume $\mathcal O_M\subset C^0$ to be concrete subsets if necessary.

My motivation is to get a structure that can communicate $\mathcal A_M$ and $\mathcal O_M$.

In a more abstract setting, we can consider a based topological space $X$ (locally compact Hausdorff and second countable, if necessary) as a generalization to $\Bbb R^n$.

  • The collection of $C^k$-diffeomorphisms on open sets of $\Bbb R^n$ generalizes to a pseudogroup $\Gamma$ of $X$: a collection of homeomorphisms from $\operatorname{Open}(X)$ which is a sub-groupoid of $\mathbf{Homeo}_X$ and contains all objects in $\operatorname{Open}(X)$, and satisfies sheaf property.

  • The sheaf of $C^k$-functions on $\Bbb R^n$ generalizes to a locally ringed space $(X,\mathcal O_X)$ where $\mathcal O_X\subset C^0_X$.

Notice that $\Gamma$ gives rise to a definition of manifold $M$ using atlas, which is a maximal collection of homeomorphisms from $M$ to $X$ such that the transition functions belong to $\Gamma$; and $\mathcal O_X$ gives rise to a definition of manifold $M$ using structure ring, which is a $\mathcal O_M$ that is locally sheaf isomorphic to $\mathcal O_X$.

My first question is, how (or whether) we can recover one from the other? For a given $\mathcal O_X$, it appears to me that $\Gamma$ should be the collection of $\phi:U\to V$ such that $f\in\mathcal O_X(V)$ iff $f\circ\phi\in\mathcal O_X(U)$ for all $f$. But how do we construct $\mathcal O_X$ canonically out of $\Gamma$? Do we need extra assumptions on these two structures?

My second question is, if $\mathcal O_X$ is sheaf of topological rings with some good topological assumption (say $\mathcal O_X(U)$ are Fréchet spaces for all $U$), can we induce topology on $\Gamma$ so that we can talk about a convergence of $\phi_\nu\to \phi_0$ in $\Gamma$? Note that we look back to $X=\Bbb R^n$ and $\mathcal O_X=C^k_{\Bbb R^n}$, the $C^k(U)$ has natural Fréchet topology given by $\{\|\cdot\|_{C^k(K)}:K\subset U\text{ precompact}\}$. So it appears to me that the pseudogroup $C^k_{\text{diffeo}}$ should be able to define the following topology

$\phi_\nu:U_\nu\to\mathbb R^n$ convergences $\phi_0:U\to\mathbb R^n$ in $C^k_{\text{diffeo}}$, if $\lim_\nu U_\nu= U$ as sets and $\bar B(0,R)\cap\partial U_\nu\to \bar B(0,R)\cap\partial U$ converges in Hausdorff distance for all $R>0$, and $\|\phi_\nu-\phi_0\|_{C^k(K)}\to0$ for all compact subsets $K\subset U$.

Is this a legitimate topology and can we talk about the "completeness" of $\Gamma$? Notice that this is not the same as the so-call étale topology on the germ spaces of $\Gamma$, which is way too strong in the $C^k$-setting.

entry.title: Robust mode estimator for binned data (with error estimation)
entry.summary:
I have to solve the problem of finding the "peak" (mode) of a certain data distribution, organized in bins. The histogram has bins with varied bin widths, and the bin contents are not Poisson distributed (they are weighted, so the error is $\sqrt{\sum w_i}$).

I have many different histogram of the same quantity in different conditions, which vary the shape even heavily, but all of them are supposed to have a peak, so the algorithm should be able to run on many different histograms, with different features (slope close to the peak, asymmetry, skewness, importance of peak wrt tails, ...), hence I need robustness.

I would also like to estiate an error on the peak!

One way I have tried is to smooth out the histogram using a simple gaussian kernel. Basically, from the histogram I build a continuous function

$f(x)= \sum_i^N n_i e^{-\dfrac{(x-x_i)^2}{2\sigma_i^2}}\dfrac{\Delta x_i}{\sqrt{2\pi}\sigma_i}$

where:

$n_i$ is the i-th bin content, x_i is the i-th bin center, $\Delta x_i$ is the i-th bin width and $\sigma_i$, the gaussian kernel smoothing factor, is set to a certain fraction of the bin width (it changes bin-by-bin).

Once I built the function, I simply find its maximum and assign it as my peak. To evaluate the error, I repeat the "fit" on variations of the histogram. The variations are built by fluctuating the bin contents according to the bin errors.

Now, this method seems ok, in the sense that the peak of the function looks close to what I would call the peak visually, but I need to evaluate its rigorousness.

I am wondering:

  1. Maybe there are better, more robust methods out there to perform such a task?
  2. How do I evaluate the bias that I introduce with the gaussian filter? That is substantially a regularization method that slightly changes my histogram by assuming continuity, so it might introduce biases.

entry.title: Is it consistent every $\mathfrak{c}$-complete ideal on $\mathfrak{c}$ is contained in the null ideal of an everywhere-defined probability measure?
entry.summary:
Let $\mathfrak{c}$ denote the continuum. Is the following statement consistent with ZFC (relative to some large cardinal assumptions)?

$\mathfrak{c}$ is a regular cardinal. Furthermore, for every nontrivial $\mathfrak{c}$-complete ideal $I$ on $\mathfrak{c}$ (i.e., $I \subset \mathcal{P}(\mathfrak{c})$; if $A \subset B$ and $B \in I$, then $A \in I$; $I$ is closed under taking unions of less than $\mathfrak{c}$ many elements; $I \neq \varnothing$; and $I \neq \mathcal{P}(\mathfrak{c})$), there is a probability measure $\mu$ on $(\mathfrak{c}, \mathcal{P}(\mathfrak{c}))$ s.t. $\mu(A) = 0$ for all $A \in I$.

Remark: It is clear that the statement implies the existence of a real-valued measurable cardinal $\leq \mathfrak{c}$, so at least a large cardinal with consistency strength of measurable cardinals is needed. Also, if, instead of $\mathfrak{c}$, we’re working with some regular cardinal $\kappa > \mathfrak{c}$, then this seems related to strongly compact cardinals as it concerns the existence of certain measures whose ideals of null sets contain a given $\kappa$-complete ideal. In that sense, perhaps the statement can be understood as a weak version of strong compactness for real-valued measurable cardinals.

The reason I’m interested in this statement is because one of my current projects has me defining a function $f$ on $\mathfrak{c}$. I need it to be measurable w.r.t. some probability measure. However, $f$ is defined in a highly non-constructive way that the only way I can make it measurable is just to make every set measurable. On the other hand, I also need a list of properties to hold for $f$ a.s., and the only thing I can prove about these properties is that the sets on which one of the properties does not hold form a $\mathfrak{c}$-complete ideal. Thus, to define the measure I need, something like the statement in this question has to hold.

Edit (1/29/26): I don't want to change the question after already posting it and I'd imagine this doesn't change the result anyway, but I just realized in my specific application, I cannot prove $I$ is actually $\mathfrak{c}$-complete, only that for every real-valued measurable cardinal $\kappa \leq \mathfrak{c}$, I can choose $I$ s.t. it is $\kappa$-complete. Again, I don't imagine this changing the answer since I think if the statement in my question is consistent, so should the statement together with the extra assumption that $\mathfrak{c}$ is real-valued measurable itself. But, just in case these are actually different, I'd accept an answer to my original question, but I'd appreciate it if the answer can show the stronger result that the statement together with $\mathfrak{c}$ being real-valued measurable is consistent.

entry.title: Example of a no-4-coplanar set in projective space over a finite field
entry.summary:
Let $\mathbb{F}_q$ be a finite field. Consider the finite field $\mathbb{F}_{q^3}$ as a $3$-dimensional vector space over $\mathbb{F}_q$. Let V be the $8$-dimensional $\mathbb{F}_q$-vector space given by $V=\{(x,y,z,t)\mid x,t\in \mathbb{F}_q, y,z\in \mathbb{F}_{q^3}\}$. Let $\mathrm{PG}(V)$ be the corresponding $7$-dimensional projective space. Let $\mathcal{S}\subseteq PG(V)$ be the following subset

$$S=\{(1,x,x^{q^2+q},x^{q^2+q+1})\mid x\in \mathbb{F}_{q^3}\}\cup \{(0,0,0,1)\}.$$

Question: How to prove that no $4$ points of $\mathcal{S}$ are coplanar? In other words the following statement:

For all $2$-dimensional planes $H$ in $\mathrm{PG}(V)$, we have $|H\cap \mathcal{S}|\leq 3$.

This seems to be fact from finite geometry and is stated without proof in Section 5.3 of https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13838. The references therein also seem to state this, however I am not able to find the exact proof.

The references seems to say something like this:

Given any $3$ points of $\mathcal{S}$, there is a unique $3$-dimensional projective linear space $L$ through them, so that $L\cap \mathcal{S}$ is contained in a twisted cubic in $L$.

Given this fact, I see that the previous statement follows. Does anyone know how to prove this statement about twisted cubic or maybe a direct way of proving that $\mathcal{S}$ is a no-$4$-coplanar set?

entry.title: What are the algebras for these operads?
entry.summary:
It is well-known that operads can be seen as "multiplicative" species of structures. This is particularly transparent in the unbiased approach (as in my paper "unbiased multicategory theory") wherein we have $I$-ary operations for any finite set $I$ (as is natural in the symmetric contexts). In fact, in this approach species are sorts of double graphs and operads are double category structures on them.

It turns out that several basic species are multiplicative in a natural way; in particular the following are in fact operads:

  1. The singletons species, with a unique structure on singletons, and none on the other sets.
  2. The species of elements, whose structures over a set $I$ are its elements.
  3. The terminal species, with a unique structure on each set.
  4. The species of families of natural numbers, whose structures over a set $I$ are families $\,\, I\to \bf N$. (Multiplication is as that of the discrete distribution monad).

Now, the algebras for the operads 1. and 3. are, respectively, sets and commutative monoids.

On the other hand it is not difficult to see that 2. and 4. are the free cartesian operads generated, respectively, by 1. and 3. (Recall that cartesian operads are a way to encode algebraic theories, essentially equivalent to Lawvere theories, but with a different perspective.) Thus the cartesian algebras for 2. and 4. are, respectively, sets and commutative monoids. Forgetting the cartesian structure of 2. and 4., we can also consider their ordinary algebras:

First question:

  • What are the ordinary algebras for 2.? Note that the arrows in 2. may be seen as families $I \to \{0,1\}$ with exactly one 1. (In fact, 2. may be considered as the "affine part" of 4.) The ordinary algebras encompass the cartesian ones, so that sets are algebras (wherein the above operations become projections). Thus, I'm asking if there are other algebras. (I suspect that the answer is negative.)

Second question:

  • What are the ordinary algebras for 4.? Since arrows in 4. are families $\,\, I \to \bf N$, an algebra on a set $A$ gives a way to evaluate combinations in $A$ with natural coefficients. Cartesian algebras on a set $A$ are $\bf N$-modules, that is commutative monoids on $A$. But for ordinary algebras, while we still have a commutative monoid structure on $A$ and $\bf N$ acts on it by homomorphisms, the conditions $(n+m)a = na + ma$ and $0a = 0$ are not required to hold.
    Thus, I'm asking if there are algebras where these conditions do not hold.

More generally, for any monoid $R$ we have the multiplicative species whose structures on $I$ are families $I\to R$. The algebras for this operad are commutative monoids on which $R$ acts by homomorphisms. If $R$ is a rig, this operad is cartesian and its cartesian algebras are $R$-modules.

entry.title: Properties of Sturm-Liouville eigenfunction expansion
entry.summary:
There are plenty of classical results about Fourier series. For instance, if a periodic function $f$ is continuously differentiable, then its Fourier series converges absolutely and uniformly to $f$.

I am looking for a reference establishing such a result (and other convergence results, such as Carleman's Theorem about pointwise convergence) in the context of expansion in the eigenfunction basis associated with a regular Sturm-Liouville problem.

That is, consider the normalized eigenfunctions $(y_n)_{n\ge 1}$ of the self-adjoint operator $L[y]:=(Py')'+Ry$ for a positive continuously differentiable function $P$ and continuous $R$, where the boundary conditions $y(a)=y(b)=0$ are imposed (and all functions are defined on $[a,b]$). Given a continuously differentiable $f\colon [a,b]\to \mathbb{R}$ with $f(a)=f(b)=0$, I look for a result proving that $\sum_{n\ge 1} \langle f,y_n\rangle y_n$ converges uniformly and absolutely to $f$. The Fourier series case is essentially $P=1$, $R=0$. I allow the general setting where eigenfunctions are defined with respect to a positive, continuous weight $Q$.

entry.title: Bound on total radius of cover of level set of monic polynomial
entry.summary:
I came across the following question: Let $P(z)$ be a monic polynomial with complex coefficients. Consider the set of points $$E = \{z \in \mathbb{C} : |P(z)| \le 1\}.$$ Prove that $E$ can be covered by a collection of disks such that the sum of their radii does not exceed $100$.

Does this question have an elementary proof? The only thing I could find online was what the AI (Gemini) produced, but it uses rather advanced results:

  1. The transfinite diameter of a monic polynomial's level set is well known, and in the above case it is equal to 1.
  2. Any compact, connected set can be covered with a collection of disks with total radius arbitrarily close to the transfinite diameter.

Is there indeed an elementary proof with the much weaker bound stated in the problem?

entry.title: System of equations with an orthogonal matrix
entry.summary:
I have six unit vectors $a_k$ and $b_k$ for $k \in \{1,2,3\}$. These are randomly drawn and are of dimension $3\times 1$.

Let $Q$ be an orthogonal matrix. I have noted that there are always$^\color{magenta}{1}$ multiple solutions to the equation system $a_k^T b_k = a_k^T Qb_k$, $k \in \{1,2,3\}$. I would like a proof that there are nontrivial solutions.

One of the solutions is of course $Q=I$ but there are further solutions. In fact, I have noted that there is always one solution such that $\det(Q)=1$.

$^\color{magenta}{1}$With probability one as we randomly select the vectors. Counterexamples of measure zero do exist.

entry.title: Synthetic $(\infty, 1)$-category theory
entry.summary:
When studying motivic homotopy theory, I find that using language of $\infty$-categories often simplifies a lot, comparing to the traditional method using model categories. Although I’m familiar with model categories now, I have only vague notions about $\infty$-category theory.

Now I want to learn the foundation seriously, without delving into combinatorics. I find that there are two approaches to a synthetic theory of $\infty$-categories: one is $\infty$-cosmos theory, studying the $(\infty, 2)$-category of $(\infty, 1)$-categories, using a category enriched over quasi-categories. Another is simplicial HoTT where we study complete segal types, which are abstraction of complete segal spaces.

For the application towards motivic spaces and motivic spectra, I want a synthetic theory rich enough to deal with

  • presentable $\infty$-categories
  • $\infty$-topoi
  • symmetric monoidal $\infty$-categories
  • the category of commutative monoids in a symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category
  • stable $\infty$-categories
  • stabilization of a pointed symmetric monoidal $\infty$-category with respect to an object $T$.

Are both synthetic methods mature enough to define and study these concepts? What would be the final stable foundation for $\infty$-category theory, in a synthetic way?

entry.title: Reference for $L^\infty$ decay of spherical harmonic coefficients for $C^{1,\alpha}$ functions
entry.summary:
Let $f \in C^{1,\alpha}(\mathbb{S}^{d-1})$, $0<\alpha<1$, and consider its spherical harmonic expansion $f = \sum_{\ell=0}^{\infty} \sum_{k} a_{\ell k} Y_{\ell k}$.

A standard result states that the coefficients satisfy the pointwise decay $$ \sup_{k} |a_{\ell k}| = O\bigl( \ell^{-1-\alpha-(d-1)} \bigr), \qquad \ell \to \infty, $$ where the implicit constant depends on the $C^{1,\alpha}$ norm of $f$.

Question: What is the canonical reference (textbook or article) where this specific theorem—linking the Hölder smoothness of a function to the $L^\infty$ decay rate of its spherical harmonic coefficients—is stated and proved?

I am looking for a source that provides the proof explicitly, not just as a corollary of a more general Sobolev embedding argument. References like Approximation Theory and Harmonic Analysis on Spheres and Balls (Dai & Xu) or classical treatises on spherical harmonics are natural candidates, but a precise citation (theorem number, page) would be ideal.

entry.title: Transfer of spectral data from stratified surfaces to embedded graphs
entry.summary:
Let $\Gamma \subset X$ be a finite connected $(q+1)$-regular Ramanujan multigraph, embedded as the 0,1-skeleta of a stratified (smooth away from $\Gamma$) 2-complex $X \subset \mathbb{R}^3$.

A generalized (or surgical) holonomy symmetry $\Psi: \Gamma \to \Gamma$ is a transformation satisfying the following properties:

For every vertex $v \in \Gamma$, the multiset of incident degrees is preserved under $\Psi$. That is, for each edge $e \sim v$, $\Psi(e)$ is incident to $\Psi(v)$, and $$ \deg(v) = \deg(\Psi(v)) = q+1. $$ Crucially $\Psi$ preserves the $(q+1)$-regularity of the graph.

The map $\Psi$ may not correspond to a global automorphism of $\Gamma$, but it induces a transformation on loops in the fundamental group $\pi_1(\Gamma)$ by redirecting or twisting edges locally. This gives rise to a group automorphism: $$ \Psi_*: \pi_1(\Gamma) \to \pi_1(\Gamma), $$ defined by how paths are rewritten under local substitutions.

Although $\Psi$ is not necessarily induced by a combinatorial automorphism $f \in \mathrm{Aut}(\Gamma) \subset \mathrm{Aut}(X)$, it induces an automorphism of the fundamental group $\pi_1(\Gamma)$, and hence preserves global homotopy structure.

Let $\rho \in \mathrm{Char}_\Gamma := \mathrm{Hom}(\pi_1(\Gamma), U(1))$ be a unitary character. The transformation $\Psi$ defines a holonomy twist: $$ \rho \mapsto \rho \circ \Psi_*. $$ This action defines a dynamical system on the representation torus $\mathrm{Char}_\Gamma \cong (S^1)^r$, producing an orbit $\rho_k := \rho_0 \circ \Psi_*^k$. Each twisted character defines a new Ihara zeta function: $$ \zeta_\Gamma(u, \rho_k) = \prod_{[P]} \left(1 - \rho_k(P) u^{\ell(P)} \right)^{-1}. $$ In general $\Psi_*$ acts nontrivially on $\pi_1(\Gamma)$, and the orbit $\{\rho_k\}$ yield distinct spectral data and evolving pole behavior. So, $\Psi$ sees both changing spectral data, and invariant spectral data depending upon the orbit class.

While the algebraic action of $\Psi$ appears abstract, it arises naturally as a geometric transformation. The construction is closely related to the optimization methods described in "A Symplectic Look at Surfaces of Revolution", A.D. Hwang, which provide a rigorous foundation for constructing structures as in the stratified 2-complex $X\subset \Bbb R^3$. We can now solve the following and then use the result as a lemma:

Optimization problem: Fix $n=3$. Consider a surface of revolution $S$ and an embedding $e:S\hookrightarrow I^3$ with endpoints $p,q \in \partial I^3$, where $\mathrm{dist}(p,q)=\sqrt{3}.$ Determine the maximal volume $$ \rho_{\max}=\max\lbrace \mathrm{vol}(S)\rbrace $$ subject to the constraints that $S$ has constant positive Gaussian curvature and is a surface of revolution. A unique solution exists and defines a canonical geometry for $S$.

This construction extends to the full complex $X=\bigcup_{i=1}^4 S_i$ by assembling four such surfaces $S_i \hookrightarrow I^3$, each solving the optimization problem along different diagonals. Slicing $X$ along the coordinate planes $x_1=1/2, x_2=1/2$ and $x_3=1/2$, the intersection of these planes with the surfaces yields a natural graph $\Gamma$, embedded within $X$. This graph inherits $(7+1)$-regularity by construction and satisfies the Ramanujan property due to spectral properties inherited from the spherical harmonics on the $S_i$'s.

Ignoring $\Psi$ for now, do the spectral properties of the Laplace-Beltrami operators on the $S_i$'s - particularly their spherical symmetry and bounded eigengvalue growth - constrain the adjacency spectrum of the resulting graph $\Gamma$? Ideally, the Laplacian eigenfunctions $\phi_k$ on the surfaces $S_i$ restrict to functions on $\Gamma$, providing a compressed spectral signature (i.e., $\phi_k\vert_{\Gamma}=\psi_k).$

It seems not unreasonable to expect the slicing of $X$ to transfer geometric harmonic data to $\Gamma$, compressing Laplace-Beltrami eigenfunctions $\phi_k$ into discrete eigenvectors $\psi_k$ for the adjacency operator $A_{\Gamma}$. Then the action of the holonomy twist $\Psi_*$ produces a family of twisted Ihara zeta functions $\zeta_{\Gamma}(u,\rho_k)$, each relfecting how parallel transport is reinterpreted under the dynamic deformation of the fundamental group. In this sense $\Psi$ acts not on the geometry, but on the gauge - the holonomy field associated to loops in $\Gamma$.

entry.title: Are the symmetric spaces $\operatorname{SU}(n)/{\operatorname{SO}(n)}$ always nontrivial in the bordism rings for $n>2$?
entry.summary:
In my recent research, I need to know if the symmetric spaces $\operatorname{SU}(n)/{\operatorname{SO}(n)}$ are always nontrivial in the unoriented and oriented bordism rings for $n>2$. (For the motivation, by Benny Cheng, the cones over them are special Lagrangians in $\mathbb{C}^{n^2+n}$. I want to know if the cones are topologically smoothable. The $n=3$ case comes from Haskins & Pacini.)

I know that for $n=3$ we are dealing with the Wu manifold, and there are many references here. For $n>3$, I tried to find references about the Stiefel-Whitney numbers of these, which by Thom, is enough for the unoriented case. However, I've only been able to locate the cohomology ring of these in Topology of Lie Groups I & II by Mimura and Toda. I don't know much algebraic topology, but I think they did not state what the Stiefel–Whitney classes are.

entry.title: Classifying space $BG$ and contractible space $EG$
entry.summary:
This question is probably not research level that's why I asked it previously on MSE a week ago. Unfortunately, it doesn't get much attention there and I thought I would try it here.

Choose an arbitrary discrete group $G$. The classifying space $BG$ of $G$ is classically constructed by forming a certain contractible $\Delta$-complex $EG$ (for one concrete construction of $EG$: see below) endowed with an action by $G$. The space $BG$ is obtained by taking the quotient $BG:= EG/G$.

The concrete construction of the $\Delta$-complex $EG$ works as follows: the $n$-simplices of $EG$ are the ordered tuples

$$[g_0,g_1,\dots,g_n] \cong \Delta_n =\left\{x\in \mathbb {R} ^{n + 1}:x=\sum _{i=0}^{n}t_{i}v_{i}\ {\text{with}}\ 0\leq t_{i}\leq 1\ {\text{and}}\ \sum _{i=0}^{n}t_{i}=1 \right\}$$

with $g_i \in G$. The $v_i$ are spanning $\Delta_n$. We obtain a $\Delta$-complex by attaching $n$-simplices to the $(n − 1)$ simplices $[g_0,g_1,\dots, \hat{g}_i,\dots,g_n]$ in standard way as a standard simplex attaches to its faces. Here $\hat{g}_i$ means that this vertex is deleted.

Question. Does there exist a constructive way to show that $EG$ is contractible. By constructive, I mean how to construct an explicit homotopy $h_t: EG \times I \to EG$ which contracts $EG$ to a point. That is $h_0(EG) = EG, h_1(EG) = \{*\}$. How does it look, concretely and geometrically?

I know some abstract arguments like Whitehead's theorem that also provide a reason for contractibility of $EG$ but this is not what I'm looking for.

I tried to define such homotopy as follows: let $p \in [g_0,\dots,g_n]$. Then $h_t$ "slides" step by step $p$ along $(n+1)$-simplex $[e,g_0,\dots,g_n]$ to $[e]$ ($e \in G$ the identity element). What I mean by "step by step along $[e,g_0,\dots,g_n]$"?

If we use again the identification $[g_0,g_1,\dots,g_n] \cong \Delta_n$ then as long as we are sitting "inside" $\Delta_n$, we can interpret the $g_i$ as spanning vectors $v_i$. Let $p = \sum _{i=0}^{n}t_{i}g_{i}$. As $[g_0,g_1,\dots,g_n] \subset [e, g_0,g_1,\dots,g_n]$ we can interpret $[g_0,g_1,\dots,g_n]$ as $x = t_{-1}e + \sum _{i=0}^{n}t_{i}g_{i} \in \Delta_{n+1}$ with $t_{-1}=0$. That is the "point" $p_e:= 1 \cdot e \in [e, g_0,g_1,\dots,g_n]$ is not contained in $[g_0,g_1,\dots,g_n]$ and we can define a unique line $l_p e$ which contains $p_e$ and is perpendicular to $[g_0,g_1,...,g_n]$ in our geometric picture $[g_0,g_1,\dots,g_n] \subset [e, g_0,g_1,\dots,g_n]$ corresponding to $\Delta_n \subset \Delta_{n+1}$.

This line uniquely intersects $[g_0,g_1,\dots,g_n]$ in a unique point $p_l$. Then we say that our homotopy slides $p$ along the unique line through $p$ and $p_l$ up to the first contact with a boundary of $[g_0,g_1,\dots,g_n]$.

Let this boundary be $[g_0,\dots, \hat{g}_i,\dots,g_n]$. Then we play the same game with $[g_0,\dots,\hat{g}_i,\dots,g_n]$ and $[e, g_0,\dots, \hat{g}_i,\dots,g_n]$.

Does this approach work? Is there a known and more conventional "textbook" way (that I still haven't found) for the construction of $EG$?

Remark: As @Luc Guyot observed the above presented construction can be looked up in Allen Hatcher's Algebraic Topology, Example 1B.7 page 89.

entry.title: Slopes of the Harder–Narasimhan filtration of a subbundle
entry.summary:
$\DeclareMathOperator\rk{rk}$Suppose $(p_1, \dotsc, p_n)$ and $(q_1, \dotsc, q_n)$ are two (non-strictly) decreasing sequences of positive real numbers. We say that $(q_1, \dotsc, q_n)$ dominates $(p_1, \dotsc, p_n)$ if $q_n \geq p_n$, $q_n+q_{n-1} \geq p_n+p_{n-1}$, …, $q_n + \dotsb + q_2 \geq p_n + \dotsb + q_2$, $q_n + \dotsb+ q_1 = p_n + \dotsb + q_1$.

For a vector bundle $F$ consider its slope $\mu(F)=\deg(F)/\rk(F)$. For a vector bundle $E$ with Harder–Narasimhan filtration $0 \neq E_1 \subset E_2 \subset \dotsb \subset E_m = E$ we consider the sequence $\mu(E_1),\dotsc,\mu(E_1), \dotsc, \mu(E_m/E_{m-1}), \dotsc, \mu(E_m/E_{m-1})$, where $\mu(E_i/E_{i-1})$ is repeated $\rk(E_i/E_{i-1})$ times, and call this sequence the degree of the Harder–Narasimhan filtration of $E$.

Suppose that $A \subset B$ are two vector bundles of the same rank $n$ such that $\deg B = \deg A + 1$. Assume that the degree of the Harder–Narasimhan filtration of $B$ is dominated by a (non-strictly) decreasing integer sequence $(d_1, \dotsc, d_n)$ such that $d_1>d_2$. Is it true that then the degree of the Harder–Narasimhan filtration of $A$ is dominated by $(d_1-1, d_2, \dotsc, d_n)$?

entry.title: Interesting examples of vacuous / void entities
entry.summary:
I included this footnote in a paper in which I mentioned that the number of partitions of the empty set is 1 (every member of any partition is a non-empty set, and of course every member of the empty set is a non-empty set):

"Perhaps as a result of studying set theory, I was surprised when I learned that some respectable combinatorialists consider such things as this to be mere convention. One of them even said a case could be made for setting the number of partitions to 0 when $n=0$. By stark contrast, Gian-Carlo Rota wrote in [Rota2], p.~15, that 'the kind of mathematical reasoning that physicists find unbearably pedantic' leads not only to the conclusion that the elementary symmetric function in no variables is 1, but straight from there to the theory of the Euler characteristic, so that 'such reasoning does pay off.' The only other really sexy example I know is from applied statistics: the non-central chi-square distribution with zero degrees of freedom, unlike its 'central' counterpart, is non-trivial."

The cited paper was: G-C. Rota, Geometric Probability, Mathematical Intelligencer, 20 (4), 1998, pp. 11–16. The paper in which my footnote appears is the first one you see here, doi: 10.37236/1027.

Question: What other really gaudy examples are there?

Some remarks:

  • From one point of view, the whole concept of vacuous truth is silly. It is a counterintuitive but true proposition that Minneapolis is at a higher latitude than Toronto. "Ex falso quodlibet" (or whatever the Latin phrase is) and so if you believe Toronto is a more northerly locale than Minneapolis, it will lead you into all sorts of mistakes like $2 + 2 = 5$, etc. But that is nonsense.

  • From another point of view, in its proper mathematical context, it makes perfect sense.

  • People use examples like propositions about all volcanoes made of pure gold, etc. That's bad pedagogy and bad in other ways. What if I ask whether all cell phones in the classroom have been shut off? If there are no cell phones in the room (that is more realistic than volcanoes made of gold, isn't it??) then the correct answer is "yes". That's a good example, showing, if only in a small way, the utility of the concept when used properly.

  • I don't think it's mere convention that the number of partitions of the empty set is 1; it follows logically from some basic things in logic. Those don't make sense in some contexts (see "Minneapolis", "Toronto", etc., above) but in fact the only truth value that can be assigned to "$F\Longrightarrow F$" or "$F\Longrightarrow T$" that makes it possible to fill in the truth table without knowing the content of the false proposition (and satisfies the other desiderata?) is $T$. That's a fact whose truth doesn't depend on conventions.
